thread.title: Human rights lecture would ‘offend’ China

title: Human rights lecture would ‘offend’ China
text:
China’s ambassador warns UK against human rights lecture George Parker, Political Editor ©Bloomberg China's president, Xi Jinping: market turbulance has shaken confidence in China’s commitment to economic reforms 
Chinese president Xi Jinping will feel “offended” if he is lectured on Beijing’s human rights record during a lavish state visit to Britain next week, China’s ambassador to the UK has warned. 
Liu Xiaoming said Britain was fast becoming the “leader” in terms of the western country with the best relations with China and said he expected the state visit to “herald a golden era for the relationship”. More NHS managers alarmed at unions reform bill 
But Mr Liu suggested the president would not take kindly to being reprimanded on human rights during his view; Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has promised to raise the issue next week. 
“We don’t shy away from talking about human rights,” Mr Liu told a press briefing. “What we are against is to use human rights to interfere with other countries’ internal affairs and to try to impose your own system on to others.” 
Mr Liu said British people “would feel offended” if China lectured Britain on human rights. “Likewise,” he added. 
Mr Xi is expected to have a private meeting with the Labour leader and will also see him at a state banquet. Mr Corbyn’s spokesman said the Labour leader would express his views “in the appropriate way”. 
David Cameron and George Osborne have energetically courted Beijing since 2012, when diplomatic relations were put into the “deep freeze” after the prime minister met the Dalai Lama in London. 
The tone of the state visit will be relentlessly upbeat on both sides, with Mr Liu saying that Britain was “coming up from behind” after losing ground to other European countries in terms of relations with Beijing.

The ambassador said the improvement in relations was down to the fact that “political mutual trust has been very much enhanced”. Mr Cameron’s critics say he has soft-pedalled on any criticism of Beijing. 
The Chinese president will spend four nights in Britain next week, visiting Buckingham Palace, giving a speech at Westminster and visiting the City of London and Manchester. 
“This is a major, historic opportunity for China-UK relations,” Mr Liu said. While Mr Osborne has spoken of a “golden decade”, the Chinese appear to have escalated the concept to “a golden era”. 
Asked whether this era might be interrupted if Britain opted to leave the EU, Mr Liu said he hoped not, but added: “We would like to see a strong Europe and a strong UK. I do hope the UK and Europe can work out an arrangement that suits both sides.” 
Mr Xi is expected to use a speech at Guildhall next Wednesday to set out how he hopes to make London the global centre for offshore Chinese finance . More video 
There is also a scramble to agree a number of Chinese inward investment deals, notably involving infrastructure, high tech, banking and other financial services for official signing ceremonies. 
There were reports that the Prince of Wales, a friend of the Dalai Lama, would boycott the state banquet at Buckingham Palace, although Clarence House said the prince would attend a lunch with the president and take tea with Mr Xi and his wife Peng Liyuan. Related Topics
